data.title: Ask Billboard: How Has Enrique Iglesiasâ€™ â€˜Bailandoâ€™ Become Such A Big Hit?
data.meta_description: In the latest mailbag: Industry execs analyze the song's barrier-breaking explosion.
data.text:
As always, submit your questions about Billboard charts, as well as general music musings, to askbb@billboard.com. Please include your first and last name, as well as your city, state and country, if outside the U.S. Or, Tweet questions to Gary Trust: @gthot20

HOW HAS ENRIQUE IGLESIASâ€™ â€˜BAILANDOâ€™ BECOME SUCH A BIG HIT?

Hi Gary,

â€œBailandoâ€ by Enrique Iglesias, featuring Descemer Bueno and Gente de Zona, climbs 23-17 on the Billboard Hot 100.

A few thoughts:

â€“ How has this song become such a big pop hit? It seems rare that a song thatâ€™s largely in Spanish, and sounds like many Latin, not necessarily pop, hits, is doing so well.

â€“ â€œBailandoâ€ joins the list of successful Spanish-language hits on the Hot 100. Iâ€™m remembering songs like â€œEres TÃºâ€ by Mocedades back in 1973 and â€œLa Torturaâ€ by Shakira, featuring Alejandro Sanz, more recently (2005).

â€“ Gente de Zona is a Cuban act, composed of people actually living in Cuba. Historically, Cuban PÃ©rez Prado had hits in the â€™50s, although he was then living in Mexico, not Cuba.

Keep up the good work and all the best,

Fernando Jerez

Havana, Cuba

Hi Fernando,

Thanks for some great historical, and geographical, context. The success of â€œBailandoâ€ is notable on many levels.

To answer your questions in reverse order, the act carries on a tradition of acts of Cuban descent (if not necessarily living in Cuba at the time of their hits). That includes Pitbull, Gloria Estefan, Jon Secada, Irene Cara and Martika. Also: Nayer, whoâ€™s featured on Pitbullâ€™s 2011 Hot 100 No. 1 â€œGive Me Everything.â€

FYI, the name Gente do Zona means â€œpeople from the neighborhood,â€ and the trio is a leader in Cuban reggaeton.

As for successful Spanish-language hits, one of the most famous ever reached the Hot 100â€™s top 40 around this time in 1987 on its way to No. 1: Los Lobosâ€™ â€œLa Bamba,â€ from the biopic of one of Latin crossover musicâ€™s pioneers, the iconic Ritchie Valens.

â€œBailandoâ€ also marks another achievement for Latin music this year. As we wrote when Romeo Santosâ€™ â€œOdio,â€ featuring Drake, debuted at No. 45 on the Hot 100 in February: â€œâ€˜Odioâ€™ claims the highest debut for a Spanish-language song in the chartâ€™s 55-year history, arriving at No. 45 as the listâ€™s highest new entry. Santos is just the third tropical act to rank as high in a first week, following Gloria Estefan, whose â€˜Heavenâ€™s What I Feelâ€™ (an English-language track) entered at No. 34 in 1998, and iconic Mambo act Perez Prado and His Orchestra, whose instrumental classic â€˜Patriciaâ€™ ranked and peaked at No. 2 the week that the Hot 100 launched (Aug. 4, 1958).â€

Santos, of course, just made more headlines when he knocked out hits at Yankee Stadium.

And, directly below â€œBailandoâ€ on this weekâ€™s Hot 100 at No. 18 is Becky Gâ€™s â€œShower.â€ Earlier this year, she reached No. 1 on Latin Digital Songs and No. 2 on Latin Airplay with â€œCanâ€™t Get Enough,â€ featuring Pitbull. While both songs are in English, she adds to the ever-increasing mix of Latin and American pop music. Mexican culture is a â€œbig part of my life,â€ she told Latina back in 2012. â€œIn my household, itâ€™s more of a Spanglish thing, aside from just the language. [Itâ€™s] the lifestyle, on both my mom and dadâ€™s sides. Family get-togethers, the soul, the music â€¦ it just comes naturally. Iâ€™m very proud to be Latina.â€

So, how has â€œBailandoâ€ (Spanish for â€œdancingâ€) hit the Hot 100â€™s top 20, given its core Latin sound and potential language barriers? Between your question and hearing the song lately so much on Z100 in New York â€“ where it sounds great, standing out, but still a fit for the format with its steadily pulsating beat and catchy verses and chorus, along with Iglesiasâ€™ friendly, familiar voice â€“ I went to Charlie Walk, executive VP of Republic Records, which is promoting the song. As it scales the Hot 100, spends a 12th week at No. 1 on Hot Latin Songs and rises 30-25 on the Pop Songs airplay chart, with only a Spanglish remix updating its original Spanish-language release (and a new Sean Paul guest rap), I asked whatâ€™s led to its success at pop radio and its run up the Hot 100.

â€œThis is a classic case of a data-driven record,â€ Walk explained. â€œThe Spanish version started building at Latin radio around February in Miami, at WMGE, WXDJ and WAMR. Plus, WYUU in Tampa. To date, those stations have played it 2,000, 1,500, 800 and 1,100 times [according to Nielsen BDS]. Thatâ€™s massive Latin airplay.

â€œWe also saw big Shazam and iTunes numbers â€“ without a single play at pop radio. Itâ€™s one of the few Latin records Iâ€™ve seen react before even pop play. So, it was delivering. We knew we had a hit.â€

Walks says that Pop Songs reporter WHYI Miami adding â€œBailandoâ€ in April was the first major step in its journey to mass appeal. â€œAgain, more sales, research and Shazam-ing. That started it on its way to becoming a hit with pop audiences.â€

WHYI program director Alex Tear calls â€œBailandoâ€ â€œcool and smooth,â€ with Iglesias â€œthe ultimate ambassador of this vibe. â€˜Bailandoâ€™ carves through the clutter of summer to make you sit back and enjoy the tropical moments. Itâ€™s now in our highest rotation with no sign of slowing down.â€

Continues Walk: â€œNow, you could say, â€˜Well, itâ€™s Miami, so obviously Enrique is going to work there.â€™ But, his last few singles didnâ€™t there. Itâ€™s not Miami â€“ itâ€™s the record. â€˜Bailandoâ€™ has a reggae/Latin sound. Itâ€™s unique, and very different from his recent songs, which just werenâ€™t all-out hits.

â€œâ€˜Bailandoâ€™ is reacting like a hit. You canâ€™t fake that: hit records react. Market-by-market, you can see that Latin airplay has led to pop play.â€

Walk notes the influence of the songâ€™s videos, too: the original version, released three months ago, has 220 million YouTube views and the English version, released a month ago, 18 million. â€œThat provides an amazing visual. Itâ€™s a one-two punch.â€

Ultimately, Walk feels that the Spanglish version of â€œBailandoâ€ proved that itâ€™s a song that translates, while still keeping the â€œessence of its DNA. He brilliantly, when we were breaking it at Latin, came up with the Spanglish version. It didnâ€™t hurt his core at Latin, while Sean Paul added another voice familiar at pop.

â€œIn all, itâ€™s a perfect storm. Other markets, including in the Midwest, are now coming on-board. All signs point to people liking it; it doesnâ€™t matter where you are. I call it a tri-coastal hit: from New York to L.A. to Miami, where it started.

â€œItâ€™s Enrique at his core â€“ it just sounds like him. He went back to being who he is. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s a hit.â€

One other key contributor to â€œBailandoâ€ is also intrigued by the song: Iglesias. â€œOf all the songs Iâ€™ve written in Spanish, thereâ€™s something about this song,â€ he recently mused. (Thanks to Billboardâ€™s executive director of Latin content and programming Leila Cobo for the quote.)

â€œThe more I listen to it, the more I seem to like it. Thereâ€™s something addictive about this song.â€

MAGIC MEN, AND WOMEN

Hi Gary,

I so look forward to Thursdays when charts update online and I can check out the latest action at Billboard!

Looking at the new Aug. 2-dated charts prompted me to research a hunch concerning the No. 1 song on the Hot 100. It turns out my hunch was right and, as unusual and random as it might be, I wanted to share it with you nonetheless.

On the Aug. 2, 2014 Hot 100, â€œRudeâ€ by MAGIC! is on top. Back on August 2, 1980, â€œMagicâ€ by Olivia Newton-John arrived at No. 1 (for a four-week reign). So, we have the same week, 34 years apart (wow, I suddenly feel old, ha), in which, in 1980, â€œMagicâ€ was the No. 1 song and, in 2014, MAGIC! is the name of the artist with the No. 1 song.

I realize itâ€™s nothing more than a coincidence, but how odd for it to be happen in the same week so many years apart. Could it be â€˜magicâ€™? (I know, pretty lame pun ğŸ™‚

Scott Nisbet

Hi Scott,

There is never such thing as a lame, or bad, pun. (We even need a theatrical performance about puns. It would be a â€¦ play on words.)

Thatâ€™s a fun stat about â€œMagic,â€ and MAGIC! And, itâ€™s another example of how music from decades ago can link with the present when it comes to the charts, just as how the artist that MAGIC! dethroned atop the Hot 100, Iggy Azalea, is now linked to the Beatles as the only acts to rank at Nos. 1 and 2 simultaneously with their first two Hot 100 hits.

(Upon relating the coincidences to my girlfriend, Michelle, in a satisfyingly rare case of her listening to me ramble on about chart trivia, she asked, â€œWhat about â€˜Abracadabraâ€™ by the Steve Miller Band and â€˜Magicâ€™ by Pilot?â€ Former programmer of Bostonâ€™s classic hits station Eagle 93.7 that she is, it turns out that â€œAbracadabraâ€ reached the top 10 this week in 1982, ahead of its two-week rule, while Pilotâ€™s â€œMagicâ€ wrapped its run in the top 10, where it peaked at No. 5, this week in 1975. Summer truly is a magical time.)

Meanwhile, happy birthday, Hot 100! With the first chart dated in August, it turns 56.

Got another good email about MAGIC!, one that also references Azaleaâ€™s seven-week No. 1 â€œFancyâ€ and Olivia Newton-John:

Hi Gary,

Continuing our monitoring of one-word titles â€“ seven of the Hot 100â€™s top 10 songs this week have one thatâ€™s just a single word â€“ â€œRudeâ€ is the latest one-word No. 1 song title by an act with a one-word name.

The list (excluding hits by one-word-named acts featuring other acts, like Santanaâ€™s â€œSmoothâ€ â€¦ featuring Rob Thomas):

â€œBabe,â€ Styx (1979)

â€œRapture,â€ Blondie (1981)

â€œAfrica,â€ Toto (1983)

â€œSara,â€ Starship (1986)

â€œVenus,â€ Bananarama (1986)

â€œAmanda,â€ Boston (1986)

â€œAlone,â€ Heart (1987)

â€œVogue,â€ Madonna (1990)

â€œJoyride,â€ Roxette (1991)

â€œUnbelievable,â€ EMF (1991)

â€œInformer,â€ Snow (1993)

â€œWeak,â€ SWV (1993)

â€œCreep,â€ TLC (1995)

â€œWaterfalls,â€ TLC (1995)

â€œMMMBop,â€ Hanson (1997)

â€œLately,â€ Divine (1998)

â€œBelieve,â€ Cher (1999)

â€œUnpretty,â€ TLC (1999)

â€œAmazed,â€ Lonestar (2000)

â€œMusic,â€ Madonna (2000)

â€œFoolish,â€ Ashanti (2002)

â€œBurn,â€ Usher (2004)

â€œSOS,â€ Rihanna (2006)

â€œIrreplaceable,â€ Beyonce (2006)

â€œDisturbia,â€ Rihanna (2008)

â€œDiamonds,â€ Rihanna (2012)

â€œRoyals,â€ Lorde (2013)

â€œRude,â€ MAGIC! (2014)

MAGIC! is, thus, the first singly-named group with a one-word No. 1 since Lonestar back in 2000.

And, as a parting gift for our departed No. 1, Iâ€™m not sure if it was mentioned that Iggy Azalea is only the third Australian woman to hit No. 1, following Helen Reddy and Olivia Newton-John, and the first since Oliviaâ€™s â€œPhysicalâ€ ruled for 10 weeks in 1981-82.

Fancy that?

Jeff Lerner

Long Island, New York

Thanks Jeff,

MAGIC! fans will also like the feature on the quartet in the new issue of Billboard magazine. Clearly, the bandâ€™s manager, Charles Chavez, made good on his mission: as he promised lead singer Nasri Atweh about â€œRude,â€ â€œIâ€™ll take it and Iâ€™ll do my best to make this the biggest song on earthâ€™.â€

HILARYâ€™S HITS

@gthot20 Hi Gary, can you please update sales of Hilary Duff in the next #AskBB?

Rei Teen ?@chokitossdd

Perfect timing, as Duff just signed with RCA Records. New single â€œChasing the Sunâ€ â€“ co-written by Colbie Caillat â€“ arrives on Tuesday (July 29) and introduces her first studio album in seven years. (She also visited Billboardâ€™s New York offices this week, although at the same time as our weekly charts department meeting. That caused social charts manager William Gruger to call the conflict â€œthe greatest dilemma Iâ€™ve ever faced.â€ â€œInvite Hilary to the meeting,â€ one Twitter follower suggested, a little too late.)

Hereâ€™s a look at the U.S. sales of Duffâ€™s studio albums, as well as her top-selling digital singles, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

Albums:

3,961,000, Metamorphosis (2003; No. 1 on the Billboard 200 for one week)

1,799,000, Hilary Duff (2004; No. 2)

1,489,000, Most Wanted (2005; No. 1, two weeks)

477,000, Santa Claus Lane (2002; No. 154)

411,000, Dignity (2007; No. 3)

Songs:

655,000, â€œCome Cleanâ€

550,000, â€œWith Loveâ€

437,000, â€œWake Upâ€

284,000, â€œFlyâ€

253,000, â€œStrangerâ€

252,000, â€œSo Yesterdayâ€

238,000, â€œSomeoneâ€™s Watching Over Meâ€

161,000, â€œOur Lips Are Sealedâ€ (with Haylie Duff)

124,000, â€œWhy Notâ€

112,000, â€œPlay With Fireâ€

â€œI took a break from music for quite awhile, but it gave me the power to choose my next steps carefully,â€ Duff says. â€œIâ€™m really proud of the album Iâ€™ve made. â€˜Chasing the Sunâ€™ is a light and fun summer song that I hope helps people feel a little more carefree.â€

BROOM CLAP

@gthot20 Two Hot 100 debuts: No. 11 â€“ â€œDirtâ€ and No. 99 â€“ â€œDustâ€

Sam Yunono ?@SamYunono

Ha, fun observation, Sam, of two new songs, by Florida Georgia Line and Eli Young Band, respectively, on the July 26 Hot 100. Thankfully, thereâ€™s also â€œRather Beâ€ by â€¦ Clean Bandit. That dance song cleans up this week, bounding 32-22.

As â€œDirtâ€ leads Hot Country Songs for a second week, the duo, Tyler Hubbard and Brian Kelley, will vault on next weekâ€™s chart as writers on Jason Aldeanâ€™s new single, â€œBurninâ€™ It Down,â€ which debuts this week at No. 42 from one day of airplay. The ballad, released at midnight on July 22, remains atop iTunes top songs list. Itâ€™s the first single from his sixth studio album, due later this year.

Notably, the song reflects another step in the evolution of FGL. After becoming known for party anthems like â€œCruiseâ€ and â€œThis Is How We Roll,â€ compositions like â€œDirtâ€ and touring partner Aldeanâ€™s new single are showing that the pair can score success with slower songs, too.

â€˜EYEâ€™ ON PETTY

With Tuesday (July 29) bringing Tom Petty and the Heartbreakersâ€™ first album since 2010, Hypnotic Eye, Billboard asked readers on Facebook for their favorite songs by the rock legends.

A sampling:

â€œFree Fallinâ€™ â€œ

Gerald Phillips, Beto G. Balderrama, DeLinda Jones, Elmer-Charles Hamilton, Asdrubal Silva

(Pettyâ€™s biggest hit as a lead act, having reached No. 7 in 1990. As featured on Stevie Nicksâ€™ â€œStop Dragginâ€™ My Heart Around,â€ he and the band rose to No. 3 in 1981.)

â€œRunninâ€™ Down a Dreamâ€

Robert Pickett, Andrew Sharp

â€œMary Janeâ€™s Last Danceâ€

Gabriel Aaron Campos, Robin Hope

â€œYou Donâ€™t Know How It Feelsâ€

Brandon Sykes, Jan Szatan Wlodarczyk

â€œAmerican Girlâ€

Deborah Carlotti

â€œListen to Her Heartâ€

Lauree Loya

â€œRefugeeâ€

Diego Contreras

â€œThe Waitingâ€

Jay Goldsworthy

â€œI Wonâ€™t Back Downâ€

Cruz Rivas

â€œLearning to Flyâ€

Debra Turnbull

â€œInto the Great Wide Openâ€

Alex Fernandez

I became a fan of Pettyâ€™s music when the Traveling Wilburys released Vol. 1 in 1988, led by the single â€œHandle With Care.â€ The song, and supergroup of Petty, Bob Dylan, George Harrison, Roy Orbison and group glue Jeff Lynne, formed when Harrison, Lynne and Orbison shared a meal and discussed the idea. They went to Dylanâ€™s house to record a B-side to Harrisonâ€™s single â€œThis Is Loveâ€; Harrison had left his guitar at Pettyâ€™s house, so he went to get it â€¦ and Petty returned with him. When the five icons rightfully decided that the resulting song, â€œCare,â€ was too good to release as a throwaway, the Wilburys were on their way to travelling up the charts.

(The origin of the bandâ€™s name? In recording Harrisonâ€™s album Cloud Nine with Lynne, some glitches occurred due to faulty equipment. Harrisonâ€™s solution: â€œWeâ€™ll bury â€™em in the mix.â€)

Liking the Wilburys (at age 14) gave my then-forming musical palette incredible rock cred. And, since there were five members (including Orbison, who passed away in December 1988), I got a seemingly endless supply of the sound in the late â€™80s and early â€™90s, starting with Cloud Nine and Vol. 1 and on through Orbisonâ€™s Mystery Girl, Pettyâ€™s Full Moon Fever, Lynneâ€™s Armchair Theatre and more.

In addition to being masters of melody, the Wilburys, and especially Petty, possessed a fun sense of whimsy, including the wacky Vol. 1 liner notes that covered the mock, but incredibly detailed, â€œhistoryâ€ of the band. Petty always seemed to have a knowing wink-and-nod in his music, which he sums up in the July 26 Billboard issue cover story. â€œThe only good thing about getting older is you get smart enough to avoid unnecessary problems. You know whatâ€™s worth spending time on and whatâ€™s not. If I had known that at 20, life would have been so much easier, but you have to experience all these things so you figure out how to find your way through the woods.â€

In honor of his newest music, and since I want to take part in Billboardâ€™s poll, too, hereâ€™s my list of my 40(-ish) favorite Tom Petty and Traveling Wilburys-related songs:

T40, â€œCalifornia,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1996

T40, â€œDo Ya,â€ Electric Light Orchestra, 1977

T40, â€œAmerican Girl,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1976

39, â€œYou Got Lucky,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1983

38, â€œEvery Little Thing,â€ Jeff Lynne, 1990

37, â€œKings Highway,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1992

36, â€œWhat Is Life,â€ George Harrison, 1971

35, â€œGot My Mind Set on You,â€ George Harrison, 1988

34, â€œItâ€™s Good to Be King,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1995

33, â€œWalls,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1996

32, â€œMy Back Pages,â€ Petty/Dylan/Harrison/Eric Clapton/Roger McGuinn/Neil Young, 1993

(A great live version of the Dylan classic, first made a hit by McGuinnâ€™s Byrds, a major influence on Pettyâ€™s music.)

31, â€œEcho,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1999

30, â€œDonâ€™t Do Me Like That,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1980

29, â€œAll Mixed Up,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1987

28, â€œAccused of Love,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1999

27, â€œEven the Losers,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1979

26, â€œInto the Great Wide Open,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1991

(Favorite lyric: â€œThey made a record and it went in the charts.â€ Second-favorite lyric, a wry look at complacency: â€œHis leather jacket had chains that would jingle / They both met movie stars, partied and mingled / Their A&R man said, â€˜I donâ€™t hear a single â€¦â€™ â€œ)

25, â€œThis Is Love,â€ George Harrison, 1988

24, â€œThatâ€™s What It Takes,â€ George Harrison, 1988

23, â€œScare Easy,â€ Mudcrutch, 2008

(I listened to the DJ on WXPK Hudson Valley, New York, outro this song when it was new that April. Why is that interesting? I stayed in the car to hear him talk about it while in a hospital parking lot, writhing in pain that turned out to be appendicitis. I was operated on that day. But, I really wanted to hear about the song. Priorities!)

22, â€œThe Last DJ,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 2002

21, â€œThe Waiting,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1981

20, â€œDonâ€™t Come Around Here No More,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1985

(One of Pettyâ€™s few songs that sounds tied to its era, with its Dave Stewart-produced polish. Still, its slickness mixed nicely with the trackâ€™s understated hook, and the top 15 Hot 100 hit continues to receive significant airplay.)

19, â€œSweet Talkinâ€™ Woman,â€ Electric Light Orchestra, 1978

18, â€œRunnin Down a Dream,â€ Tom Petty, 1989

17, â€œFree Fallinâ€™,â€ Tom Petty, 1990

16, â€œRunaway Trains,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1987

15, â€œYou Got It,â€ Roy Orbison, 1989

14, â€œSquare One,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 2006

13, â€œLearning to Fly,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1991

12, â€œFlirting With Time,â€ Tom Petty, 2007

11, â€œNot Alone Any More,â€ Traveling Wilburys, 1988

10, â€œWildflowers,â€ Tom Petty, 1994

9, â€œA Face in the Crowd,â€ Tom Petty, 1990

8, â€œI Wonâ€™t Back Down,â€ Tom Petty, 1989

7, â€œEnd of the Line,â€ Traveling Wilburys, 1989

6, â€œLift Me Up,â€ Jeff Lynne, 1990

5, â€œWhat Would It Take,â€ Jeff Lynne, 1990

4, â€œAll the Wrong Reasons,â€ Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers, 1991

(I always thought that the song was the sonic sequel to â€œFree Fallinâ€™.â€ Never a single, it still brought an addictive guitar hook, as well as a commentary following the greed-is-good â€™80s: â€œWell, she grew up hard and she grew up fast / In the age of television / And she made a vow to have it all / It became her new religion.â€)

3, â€œHandle With Care,â€ Traveling Wilburys, 1988

2, â€œInside Out,â€ Traveling Wilburys, 1991

And â€¦

1, â€œA Higher Place,â€ Tom Petty, 1995

Hidden gem â€œPlaceâ€ is from 1994â€™s Wildflowers. (The cut reached No. 12 on Mainstream Rock Songs the following year.) For its 20th anniversary, Petty will offer previously unreleased songs from the setâ€™s sessions this fall. â€œThere are some beautiful songs,â€ he says. â€œI think people who liked Wildflowers will certainly feel like they got part two of that record.â€
